word.entryDescription: light signals on the road which tell you when to stop and go
word.entryExample: You need to turn left at the traffic lights.

word.entryDescription: a serious play that ends sadly, often with the death of the main character
word.entryExample: What do you know about Greek tragedy?

word.entryDescription: to teach or to learn how to do a job or activity
word.entryExample: Sam is training to be a journalist.

word.entryDescription: somebody who is being instructed in how to do a particular job
word.entryExample: The Daily News seeks a trainee reporter to join its staff in its newsroom this summer.

word.entryDescription: a leisure or sports shoe
word.entryExample: You need good trainers when you go for a run.

word.entryDescription: the process of teaching and learning how to do a job or activity
word.entryExample: You'll receive training on the job.

word.entryDescription: an electric passenger vehicle on tracks which usually travels around city streets
word.entryExample: Before the 1970s most people walked or travelled by bus or tram to their workplace.

word.entryDescription: changed into something else
word.entryExample: Wow! Your renovations have completely transformed the place!

word.entryDescription: to express the meaning of a word, sentence, etc. in a different language
word.entryExample: The teacher asked me to translate the word.

word.entryDescription: describes a material, substance, etc that you can see through
word.entryExample: If you like light, bright spaces, you could choose a completely transparent glass house like this one.

word.entryDescription: rubbish (things you do not want and throw away)
word.entryExample: Take out the trash, please.

word.entryDescription: to make a journey or visit a place
word.entryExample: Steve wants to travel into space.

word.entryDescription: somebody who works in an office where you can book travel and holidays
word.entryExample: William rang the travel agent in order to check the hotel booking.

word.entryDescription: a ticket usable on more than one journey or mode of public transport within a specific area using bulk or discounted payment
word.entryExample: First, touch your travel card on the blue reader to start.

word.entryDescription: someone who is travelling or who often travels
word.entryExample: Sarah told us why she is different from most travellers.

word.entryDescription: a wide flat object used to carry food and drinks on
word.entryExample: I carried the tea in on a tray.

word.entryDescription: a collection of very valuable things, or one thing of great value
word.entryExample: The treasure is somewhere on this island.

word.entryDescription: a game in which the players try and find something hidden by reading short messages
word.entryExample: Sam and his friends had a treasure hunt.

word.entryDescription: a place in which private or public funds are kept
word.entryExample: Some precious stones were found in the treasury of the old castle.

word.entryDescription: to deal with a health problem using medicine, care, exercises, etc
word.entryExample: Can yoga be used to treat asthma and eczema?

word.entryDescription: the process of dealing with a health problem using medicine, care, exercises, etc
word.entryExample: Acupuncture is thought to be the most ancient treatment based on Chi.

word.entryDescription: a tall plant with leaves and a wooden trunk and branches
word.entryExample: There's an apple tree in my garden.

word.entryDescription: a small wooden house built among the branches of a tree for children to play in
word.entryExample: We have a treehouse in our garden.

word.entryDescription: very, greatly
word.entryExample: It was tremendously exciting when Apollo 11 lifted off.

word.entryDescription: currently popular or fashionable
word.entryExample: Shorter skirts are trendy again this year.

word.entryDescription: (plural 'tributaries') a river or stream that flows into a larger river or a lake
word.entryExample: Lyne Water is a tributary of the River Tweed.

word.entryDescription: clever action that seems like magic, performed to entertain people
word.entryExample: The magician performed sawing a person in half. This trick is quite simple.

word.entryDescription: something that you do to cheat someone
word.entryExample: The elephants are really intelligent. One of their tricks is to cover watering holes with bits of wood to stop other animals from drinking it.

word.entryDescription: a journey to a place, which might include staying there
word.entryExample: Adam went on the school trip a short time ago.

word.entryDescription: to fall or almost fall after hitting something with your foot while walking or running
word.entryExample: Don't trip over the rug and fall.

word.entryDescription: triple glass window panes separated by an air (or other gas) filled space to reduce heat transfer
word.entryExample: Thanks to triple-glazed windows passive houses are well-insulated.

word.entryDescription: an object (such as a cup or sculpture) that is given as a prize for winning a competition
word.entryExample: The captain is holding the trophy his team has just won.

word.entryDescription: of or from the tropics
word.entryExample: Africa, Asia and America all have hot tropical areas where special forests and vegetation grow.

word.entryDescription: a piece of clothing that covers your legs and lower half of your body
word.entryExample: These are my favourite trousers.

word.entryDescription: a truck is the same as a lorry especially in American English
word.entryExample: He plays with toy cars and trucks.

word.entryDescription: an elephant's long soft nose, which it can use to hold things
word.entryExample: The elephant moved its trunk to smell the flowers.

word.entryDescription: honest; not telling lies
word.entryExample: We must be truthful with each other.

word.entryDescription: to put on an item of clothing in a shop to see if it is right for you
word.entryExample: I'm trying on the white woollen jumper.

word.entryDescription: a very large wave often caused by an earthquake that can do a lot of damage when it reaches land
word.entryExample: It is not certain whether global warming can activate volcanoes and tsunamis.

word.entryDescription: underground railway
word.entryExample: We'll catch the tube instead of the bus.

word.entryDescription: a machine which uses hot air to dry wet clothes
word.entryExample: If you put wet clothes in a tumble dryer, they become dry.

word.entryDescription: a large sea fish whose flesh is commonly sold in tins
word.entryExample: While we were in Thailand we ate fresh tuna.

word.entryDescription: a passage built underground
word.entryExample: How long does it take to get through this tunnel?

word.entryDescription: an engine or machine with a wheel where the energy of water turns the wheel and makes power
word.entryExample: The wind's energy is passed through giant turbines which convert their energy to electricity.

word.entryDescription: meat which comes from a bird which looks like a large chicken
word.entryExample: Turkey is popular at Christmas.

word.entryDescription: to change direction
word.entryExample: Go down Church Street and then turn into East Road.

word.entryDescription: to lower the amount of volume, heat, light, etc produced by a device
word.entryExample: My mum always makes me turn down my music.

word.entryDescription: to become something different
word.entryExample: You don't have to turn into a great sports person. You can just go for long walks or go swimming two times a week.

word.entryDescription: to stop the supply of electricity to a device
word.entryExample: If you're trying to study, you should turn off your phone.

word.entryDescription: have an unexpected result
word.entryExample: It turned out that it was a security test aimed at raising passengers' awareness.
